results.title:
Chronophotographic prints
Bird in Flight
results.credit_line: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy
results.brief_description: French scientist Étienne-Jules Marey’s chronophotographic technique captured kinetic motion through multiple exposures in one photo. He used a photographic rifle with a revolving cylinder that shot 12 frames a second.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy

results.title: Attack of the strange insects from Uranus
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This mockumentary, depicting the zombie apocalypse, contains a hilarious collection of violence and gore. (Note that some scenes may disturb some viewers).

results.title: Robin Campbell: old feller now: memories of a Muruawarri
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: Robin Campbell, an old man of the Murrawarri tribe of the far north west of New South Wales recalls, through dramatic re-enactments by his young relations, how he was taught, as a child, to hunt the emu and make animal tracks, and how he worked as a drover in the 1930’s and 40’s. Narrated by Bill Reid.
results.title_for_label: Robin Campbell: old feller now: memories of a Muruawarri
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara and Goodgabah Productions

results.title: Fishtank
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
A high-rise flat in the U.K. Midlands. Ray is the father who drinks, Liz the mother, Jason the brother. There are some animals and the brother kills flies. The older brother films them with his handycam - intently observing whatever is going on.

In 1996 Richard Billingham’s ‘Ray’s a Laugh’ was hailed as the photo book of the decade. His photographs were one of the talking points of ‘Sensation’. Billingham has now made ‘Fishtank’, a commission for television by Artangel in collaboration with film-maker Adam Curtis and Illuminations TV for BBC2’s acclaimed TV series. The ‘video verite’ of Fishtank is contained within the compressed space/fishtank of the flat. Sometimes they talk, sometimes they argue. Billingham’s film registers the emotional temperature of this space and the family who live there with a closeness that transcends camera conventions. Like the paintings of Lucian Freud, Billingham crafts a terrible beauty from the landscape of family life and its patterns of pathos, despair and hope.

results.title: The Pursuit of happiness
results.brief_description: This is set in Fremantle, Western Australia during the build-up to the America’s Cup Yacht Race and the controversy surrounding the visit of US nuclear warships. It is about human relationships and international issues, the threat of nuclear war and people’s attitudes to the future. The film blends scenes of fact and fiction to portray the story of a family in conflict and one woman’s growing awareness about the choices she must make.

results.title: What I have written
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Peter Sainsbury, Beyond Films and Early Works
results.brief_description:
Australian marital drama, which explores notions of identity and fidelity. Sorel and Christopher’s marriage is in the process of recovering from an extended period of alienation, when Christopher, a writer and poet, suffers an apparently fatal stroke. Shortly afterwards Sorel receives a manuscript written by her husband, of which she knows nothing. To her chagrin it reads as a thinly veiled account of their disintegrating marriage and a recent affair of her husband’s conducted whilst they were holidaying in Paris. Sorel reads Christopher’s novella and discovers his secret erotic yearnings for others and disgust for her. But is it true? Sorel can only hopelessly rage at her comatose husband whilst attempting to unravel their past. Assuming a sophisticated style, the film utilises stills, black and white photography, and a shifting voiceover to convey a multi-layered narrative. But despite its stylish aesthetic, an over reliance on such devices, which attempts to instil the mise-en-scene with a sense of mystery and eroticism, stagnates the narrative and exacerbates the

Credits: Producer, Peter Sainsbury, John Hughes ; director, John Hughes ; writer, John A. Scott ; photography, Dion Beebee ; music, David Bridie, John Phillips, Helen Mountford ; editing, Uri Mizrahi.
Cast: Angie Milliken, Jacek Koman, Fiona Stewart, Gillian Jones, Martin Jacobs.

results.title: Conrad Martens
results.creator_credit: Clytie Jessop and National Trust of Australia
results.brief_description: Concerns the life and work of early Colonial artist Conrad Martens whose paintings and sketches are a valuable historical record of Australia. Deals with Marten’s work in England, his voyage on “The Beagle” and his friendship with Charles Darwin, and his output in Sydney.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clytie Jessop and National Trust of Australia

results.title: Dartmouth
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Dartmouth Dam, on the Mitta Mitta River in Victoria, has been designed to manage the waters of the River Murray for irrigation and urban needs. This film tells the story of the making of Dartmouth Dam including the study of plant and animal life. Reminiscences about the old Dartmouth township, and plans for the new town of Dartmouth. Narrated by Simon Chilvers.

results.title: Shadow panic
results.brief_description: I am the dreamer, the redhead. I search for hidden treasure: which fragment would yield gold, which memory would haunt forever? Three women, strangers to each other, yet their lives seem inexplicably linked. “Shadow Panic” is a short experimental film about internal and external states of emergency, about personal and collective shadows, about resistance and spirit.
